title.narrative: Managing Access to Unused Logging Roads: A Practical Means to Protecting Tiger Prey Populations in Primorye, Russia

description.narrative: "The purpose of this proposal is to demonstrate measurable changes in human access and wildlife population numbers, particularly ungulates, resulting from logging road closures in order to prove the effectiveness of closures for tiger conservation. This would be done by: (a) closing unused logging roads; (b) measuring changes in wildlife populations; (c) measuring changes in human use; (d) designing closures that facilitate effective law enforcement; and (e) promoting road closures as a necessary component of FSC certification...Specifically the applicant would select six roads within the Maksimovka River drainage and close three of these roads once the ground thaws in the spring 2013 and then (a) measure changes in wildlife populations; (2) measure changes in human use; (3) design closures that facilitate effective law enforcement; and (4) promote road closures as a necessary component of FSC certification."

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Increasing the Capacity of Russian nature Reserves and parks to conserve Imperiled Habitats and Species

description.narrative: This project provides funding for scientific field work within the Wrangel Island Federal Biosphere Reserve in Russia specifically pertaining to the population of snow geese shared with the United States. Additionally, the proposal will fund a small grants competition for Russian nature reserves and parks. USFWS and the recipient will work collaboratively on advertising the grants competition to Russias nature reserves and parks, receiving and translating proposals. The recipient will organize one proposal review panel in Russia, and USFWS will organize one review panel in the United States. Funding decisions will be made jointly between USFWS and ANO Ekosentr Zapovedniki, and USFWS will have final approval for all final funding decisions. USFWS and ANO Ekosentr Zapovedniki will communicate with the sub-grantees and collaboratively monitor technical and administrative performance. Sub-grants funded by this award will improve the protected areas law enforcement, visitor center services, reserve management, and biodiversity conservation through training courses, the purchase of patrolling equipment, and the increased presence of law enforcement officers. Species to benefit include the critically endangered saiga antelope, Amur tiger, polar bear, walrus, Far Eastern leopard, snow goose, and Asiatic black bear.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Conserving Amur Tigers and their Prey by Expanding Law Enforcement Monitoring to Non-..Protected Areas

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to 1) increase the effectiveness of anti-poaching efforts outside protected areas within the range of Amur tigers in the RFE. This would be done by: (a) collaboratively designing, developing, and implementing a SMART-based law enforcement monitoring system for unprotected lands; (b) improving forage conditions for ungulates by planting feed plots; and (c) improving tiger monitoring through use of camera trapping in Southern Valley.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Wildlife Without Borders-Eurasia

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is for the recipient to conduct a small-grants competition to benefit the conservation of the critically endangered saiga antelope. In line with the Medium Term Work Programme for 2011-2015 associated with the Convention on Migratory Species Memorandum of Understanding (MoU), sub-grant projects will fall under the following themes: MoU implementation; anti-poaching; sustainable use and trade; human factors; awareness; mapping distributions; protected areas; monitoring; captive breeding (only if relevant to conservation in the wild). Saiga Conservation Alliance will consult with USFWS before any sub-grants are awarded. All sub-grant projects will be carried out with the support of range state governments.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Developing a Standardized Methodology for Camera Trap Monitoring of Amur Tigers in..Protected Areas in the Russian Far East

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to replace the existing Amur tiger monitoring system in Russia based on tracks with a standardized methodology that relies on use of camera traps. The primary goal of this project is to implement this new system in all federally protected areas that hold important habitat for tigers in the Russian Far East. The secondary goal is to share this approach with appropriate entities in northeast China in an attempt to develop coordinated, trans-boundary survey protocols. This will be done by: 1) institutionalizing and expanding existing camera trap efforts to a total of six protected areas; 2) ensuring there is a standardized methodology used at all sites and obtaining governmental approval of the methodology; and 3) facilitating information sharing by developing a photographic database and beginning coordination of camera trap surveys and photographic databases with stakeholders in northeast China.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Improving law enforcement to recover tigers in Sikhote-Alin Bioshere Zapovednik

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to improve law enforcement efforts in Sikhote-Alin Biosphere Zapovednik over the next year by increasing the effectiveness of inspectors. This will be done by: 1) purchasing two 4-wheelers to increase access to interior of SABZ in summer; 2) re-initiating the reward system established through SMART with clear minimum standards for foot patrols and hours; 3) establishing a special reward system (Directors Reward) that focuses on concrete results; 4) organizing joint raids with police and the regional wildlife inspector; 5) creating clearly defined teams, with team leaders responsible for results; 6) organizing two trainings per year for the patrol teams; and 7) developing a fitness regime to help build morale.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Mitigating Human-Tiger Conflict in the Russian Far East

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to reduce the loss of wild tigers by mitigating human-tiger conflicts. Project will support Russian government agencies in their human-tiger conflict mitigation efforts, monitor the movements of young tigers rehabilitated and released back to the wild, and establish long-term monitoring protocols for rehabilitated tigers.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Minimizing the impacts of human activities on Amur tigers in the Russian Far East through improved monitoring and law enforcement

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to evaluate the effects of tourism on tiger movements, distribution and space use, and develop a tourist management plan that contains quantitative guidelines for mitigating those effects, and provide support for a database computer specialist to work with Zov Tigra National Park and Lazovsky State Nature Reserve during and after they transition from the MIST to the SMART law enforcement framework. This work is in collaboration with Wildlife Conservation Society and Phoenix Fund who together support inspector training and bonuses.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Strengthening law enforcement to protect Amur tigers in Southeast Primorye the Russian Far East

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to continue to strengthen the Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool (SMART) patrol approach that will monitor and mitigate the effect of illegal human activities on Amur tigers in Lazovsky State Nature Reserve (LZ) and Zov Tigra National Park (ZT). Project will support expanded SMART approach training, and the use of standard camera trapping techniques, allowing to measure the effectiveness of activities by tracking changes in tiger abundance. To minimize the risk of illegal human activities on tigers in LZ and ZT, and continue a camera trap monitoring program in ZT, LZ, and Medved Hunting lease, the project has the following objectives: (1) Strengthen and expand ZSLs support for SMART in LZ and ZT by supporting national protected area management, building capacity of park rangers and continued support for the SMART database computer specialist; (2) Continue the long-term camera trap monitoring program in ZT, LZ, and Medved Hunting lease.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Contributed Funds

title.narrative: Strengthening law enforcement to protect Amur tigers in Southeast Primorye the Russian Far East

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to continue to strengthen the Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool (SMART) patrol approach that will monitor and mitigate the effect of illegal human activities on Amur tigers in Lazovsky State Nature Reserve (LZ) and Zov Tigra National Park (ZT). Project will support expanded SMART approach training, and the use of standard camera trapping techniques, allowing to measure the effectiveness of activities by tracking changes in tiger abundance. To minimize the risk of illegal human activities on tigers in LZ and ZT, and continue a camera trap monitoring program in ZT, LZ, and Medved Hunting lease, the project has the following objectives: (1) Strengthen and expand ZSLs support for SMART in LZ and ZT by supporting national protected area management, building capacity of park rangers and continued support for the SMART database computer specialist; (2) Continue the long-term camera trap monitoring program in ZT, LZ, and Medved Hunting lease.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Contributed Funds

title.narrative: Expanding and Institutionalizing SMART throughout Amur Tiger Ranger in Russia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to increase tiger numbers in the Russian Far East. Within the context of this proposal the goal is to improve tiger antipoaching effectiveness at federal-level protected areas in Russia. The project has the following objectives: (1) Continue to support Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool (SMART) patrolling programs in five existing protected areas where tigers and leopards exist in the Russian Far East; (2) Introduce and assist in SMART patrol monitoring and adaptive patrol management at Bolshekhekhtsirskii Zapovednik (BZ) and Annui National Park (ANP); (3) Build protection capacity at BZ and ANP; and (4) Foster institutionalization of SMART patrol monitoring and management at these sites.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Contributed Funds

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Agency for International Development, Development Assistance
Agency for International Development, Development Assistance

title.narrative: Population Monitoring of Amur Tigers in Russia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to improve annual biological monitoring of tigers to better inform conservation management both in and out of protected areas. The project has the following objectives: (1) Continue monitoring at three existing protected areas while, where possible, expanding camera trap monitoring beyond the boundaries of the protected areas; (2) Expand and improve camera trap monitoring of tigers at a fourth protected area; (3) Monitor forest roads outside protected areas; and (4) Continue to promote joint annual reporting on large cat camera trap monitoring and a coordinated single database in Russia.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

The project has the following objectives: (1) Continue monitoring at three existing protected areas while, where possible, expanding camera trap monitoring beyond the boundaries of the protected areas; (2) Expand and improve camera trap monitoring of tigers at a fourth protected area; (3) Monitor forest roads outside protected areas; and (4) Continue to promote joint annual reporting on large cat camera trap monitoring and a coordinated single database in Russia.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Rapid Response and SMART Law Enforcement for Tiger Protection in Southeast Primorye, Russian Far East

description.narrative: We propose to build upon our SMART Approach, particularly by training new Protected Area Management staff, creating Rapid Response teams that will be trained and equipped to respond to illegal incursions within our conservation landscape, and continuing critical long-term tiger monitoring.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Rapid response and SMART Law Enforcement for tiger protection in Southeast Primorye,.Russian Far East

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to secure the future of Amur tigers in the Russian Fareast. The objectives and activities are as follows: (1) Continue Spatial Monitoring And Reporting Tool (SMART) patrol approach, and appropriate capacity development of the new United Administrations of Lazovsky Zapovednik and Zov Tigra Park (UALZZT) administration and staff; (2) Develop, train and equip two Rapid Response Teams (RRT), working with UALZZT; and, (3) Improve long-term monitoring of tiger populations in ULAZZT, by maintaining and upgrading the camera grid and camera trap data analysis tool.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Tiger conservation in the Russian Far East

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to increase tiger numbers to carrying capacity in the Russian Far East. Objectives include, (1) Monitoring tigers and their threats; (2) Improving estimates of tiger prey abundance; (3) Increasing law enforcement control and improve anti-poaching patrol quality of Ussuriskii Reserve; (4) Mitigating impacts of Typhoon Lionrock on tiger habitat by clearing trails post typhoon; (5) Improving quality of care for tigers at the Alekseevka tiger rehabilitation center, by updating veterinary equipment and infrastructure; and, (6) Promoting tiger-friendly roads management outside protected areas.

title.narrative: Encouraging Locals to Support Amur Tiger Recovery in Northern Range

description.narrative: 1.) Educate local communities in JAP on the importance of peaceful co-existence with Amur tigers, 2.) Hold meetings with local hunters, villagers, and teachers, raise their awareness about co-existence with tigers and the importance of tiger conservation, and 3.) Produce and distribute outreach materials, and assist Bastak Nature Reserve in organizing Tiger Day Festival in Birobidzhan.

title.narrative: Safeguarding Amur tiger conservation, through strengthening the effectiveness and funding of UALZZT protected area

description.narrative: There are around 500 individual Amur tigers today. The Zoological Society of London (ZSL) has been working in Lazovsky Zapovednik State Nature Reserve, and Zov Tigra National Park, using camera traps to monitor tiger density, reproduction, survival, and distribution. These two protected areas merged to form the United Administrations of Lazovsky Zapovednik and Zov Tigra National Park (UALZZT). ZSL and NGO partners have strengthened anti-poaching and law enforcement, through the SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) approach and the Forest Eyes Initiative (enhanced surveillance through camera trap technology). Project objectives are to, (1) Enhance the long-term tiger monitoring program in UALZZT by maintaining and upgrading the camera trap grid and expanding the grid to an additional 500km2; (2) Improve the long-term poacher cam surveillance Forest Eyes Initiative system to sustain and enhance anti-poaching in UALZZT by comparing and evaluating systems and identifying vulnerable gaps in monitoring; and, (3) Strengthen capacity for effective and sustainable protected area management by enabling partnerships between tiger range states, supporting a knowledge exchange visit and partnership between two tiger range states, Russia and Nepal.

title.narrative: Building SMART Anti-Poaching Methods to Protect Tigers and their Prey in Russia

description.narrative: Since 2010, one of the Wildlife Conservation Societys primary activities in Russia has been to target conservation efforts at key protected areas with Amur tigers. The goal is to improve law enforcement at these sites to increase population sizes of tigers and their prey, and to increase the effective protected area of these source sites. WCS works with protected area staff to utilize a management system called SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool), which increases the efficiency and accountability of their anti-poaching programs. To date, these efforts are paying dividends. All protected areas where WCS have partnered, have shown improvements in anti-poaching efforts, and tiger numbers have largely remained stable or increased. Project objectives are to: (1) Support proper implementation of the SMART system at seven existing protected areas with tigers in Russia; (2) Improve capacity at sites to provide protection; and, (3) Foster institutionalization of SMART patrol monitoring and management at these sites.

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Contributed Funds

title.narrative: Combatting illegal logging in Korean broadleaf forests in the Russian Far East to conserve the.habitat of the Amur tiger

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to, (1) Develop response teams and build their capacity to ground-truth alerts from the KEDR alarm system and enforce the law against illegal loggers in Amur tiger habitats, (2) Improve digital information sharing on the quality of Amur tiger habitat and forest management in Korean-pine broadleaf forests, and, and, (3) Assist with controlling illegal logging in Amur tiger habitats. Well trained and equipped mobile response teams will be established in Khabarovsk and Primorsky provinces. Project will support the development of a database on forest concessions, forest companies, and exporters of Mongolian oak, provide weekly updates on forest cover change, and make available information on forest concessions and maps of High Conservation Value Forests on an open access data portal; Monitor KEDR implementation and efficiency of law enforcement; Cross check information from KEDR alerts, which uses the GLAD (Global Land Analysis and Discovery) algorithm alert system to alert authorities to forest cover change using medium resolution and open access (10-15 pixel) multispectral space images from Landsat and Santinel satellites. KEDR aggregates GLAD alert data, compares it with the existing forest management database, and a special control center under the administration of the Forest Department informs relevant authorities on possible unauthorized activities in the forest.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: The use of performing arts in environmental education to improve Amur tiger conservation

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to raise peoples awareness, about the state of the Amur tiger population with the use of the performing art by, (1) holding drama lessons on ecological topics for school children, agencies, NGOs, (2) staging theatrical performances devoted to Amur tiger conservation issues both in the cities and villages, (3) holding a workshop on the use of performing arts in environmental education for educators and teachers, and, (4) providing ecological theater with stage supplies and costumes.

title.narrative: Strengthening tiger conservation initiatives through building an ecological evidence base in Nandhaur Wildlife Sanctuary, India

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to, (1) Enhance Uttarkhand Forest Departments (UKFD) capacity to conduct tiger and prey base monitoring including the analysis of scientific data, (2) Conduct annual camera trapping and line transect surveys to estimate tiger and prey base density within the newly extended Nandhaur Wildlife Sanctuary, and, (3) Strengthen existing law enforcement interventions by providing park authorities with key data on tiger and prey base presence as well as threats based on monitoring results.

title.narrative: Combating Poaching and Trafficking of Critically Endangered Sturgeon 2

description.narrative: (1) river patrols and support to frontline law enforcement officers to effectively counter wildlife trafficking; (2) engaging local fishers and civil society groups to support sturgeon conservation; (3) monitoring the trade and identifying the species and origin of trafficked sturgeon; (4) training coastal fishers on safe release techniques, legal fishing methods, and collection of scientific data; (5) data gathering on bycatch rates and international shipping routes for smuggled sturgeon, including identifying the feasibility of a transboundary framework for the Black Sea; (6) forming a team of Georgian experts to address sturgeon trafficking; and (7) raising international awareness of sturgeon. This project will build upon the outputs and successes of a previous USFWS-supported one-year project (2017-2018) that enabled FFI to launch sturgeon-focused activities in the region.

title.narrative: Robust Estimates of Tiger and Wild Boar Populations Across the Russian Far East,

description.narrative: , (1) improve and expand camera trap monitoring of Amur tigers range-wide, and (2) improve estimates of abundance and seasonal movements of wild boar. Project objectives are to: (1) continue collaboration in Russian protected areas to improve camera trap monitoring of tigers; (2) conduct large-scale cameras trapping both inside and outside protected areas; and, (3) develop methods for capture and handling wild boar, and collect data of daily travel distances and seasonal movements.

title.narrative: SMART ANTI-POACHING IN PROTECTED AND UNPROTECTED TIGER HABITAT IN RUSSIA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to (1) Optimize and institutionalize Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool (SMART) patrolling systems at federal-level protected areas with tigers, and expand the use of SMART in the northern portion of tiger habitat in the Russian Far East; 2) Sustain and, where necessary, implement monitoring programs at key sites to document population trends of tigers and their prey; and (3) Conduct ecological studies of prey species to better inform conservation management decisions.
